events.name: touchmove
events.summary: Fired as soon as the device detects movement of a touch.
events.description: Event coordinates are always relative to the view in which the initial touch occurred

properties.name: y
properties.summary: Y coordinate of the event from the source view's coordinate system.

properties.name: x
properties.summary: X coordinate of the event from the source view's coordinate system.

properties.name: bubbles
properties.summary: True if the event will try to bubble up if possible.

properties.name: cancelBubble
properties.summary: Set to true to stop the event from bubbling.

properties.name: source
properties.summary: Source object that fired the event.

properties.name: type
properties.summary: Name of the event fired.

events.name: touchcancel
events.summary: Fired when a touch event is interrupted by the device.
events.description: A touchcancel can happen in circumstances such as an incoming call to allow the UI to clean up state.

properties.name: y
properties.summary: Y coordinate of the event from the source view's coordinate system.

properties.name: x
properties.summary: X coordinate of the event from the source view's coordinate system.

properties.name: bubbles
properties.summary: True if the event will try to bubble up if possible.

properties.name: cancelBubble
properties.summary: Set to true to stop the event from bubbling.

properties.name: source
properties.summary: Source object that fired the event.

properties.name: type
properties.summary: Name of the event fired.

events.name: touchend
events.summary: Fired when a touch event is completed.
events.description: On the Android platform, other gesture events, such as longpress or swipe, cancel touch events, so this event may not be triggered after a touchstart event.

properties.name: y
properties.summary: Y coordinate of the event from the source view's coordinate system.

properties.name: x
properties.summary: X coordinate of the event from the source view's coordinate system.

properties.name: bubbles
properties.summary: True if the event will try to bubble up if possible.

properties.name: cancelBubble
properties.summary: Set to true to stop the event from bubbling.

properties.name: source
properties.summary: Source object that fired the event.

properties.name: type
properties.summary: Name of the event fired.

events.name: click
events.summary: Fired when the device detects a click against the view.
events.description:
There is a subtle difference between singletap and click events.

A singletap event is generated when the user taps the screen briefly without moving their finger. This gesture will also generate a click event.

However, a click event can also be generated when the user touches, moves their finger, and then removes it from the screen.

On Android, a click event can also be generated by a trackball click.

properties.name: y
properties.summary: Y coordinate of the event from the source view's coordinate system.

properties.name: x
properties.summary: X coordinate of the event from the source view's coordinate system.

properties.name: bubbles
properties.summary: True if the event will try to bubble up if possible.

properties.name: cancelBubble
properties.summary: Set to true to stop the event from bubbling.

properties.name: source
properties.summary: Source object that fired the event.

properties.name: type
properties.summary: Name of the event fired.

events.name: singletap
events.summary: Fired when the device detects a single tap against the view.

events.name: complete
events.summary: Fired when movie playback ends or a user exits playback.
events.description: On iOS, the reason property is only included if this information is available.

properties.name: reason
properties.summary: Reason that playback ended.

properties.name: success
properties.summary: Indicates if the video was played successfully. User exit counts as a success. Returns true if reason is not VIDEO_FINISH_REASON_PLAYBACK_ERROR, false otherwise.

properties.name: error
properties.summary: Error message, if any returned. Will be undefined if success is true.

properties.name: code
properties.summary: Error code. Error code will be 0 if success is true, nonzero otherwise. If the error was generated by the operating system, that system's error value is used. Otherwise, this value will be -1.

properties.name: bubbles
properties.summary: True if the event will try to bubble up if possible.

properties.name: cancelBubble
properties.summary: Set to true to stop the event from bubbling.

properties.name: source
properties.summary: Source object that fired the event.

properties.name: type
properties.summary: Name of the event fired.

events.name: durationavailable
events.summary: Fired when the video duration is available.

properties.name: duration
properties.summary: Video duration, in milliseconds.

properties.name: bubbles
properties.summary: True if the event will try to bubble up if possible.

properties.name: cancelBubble
properties.summary: Set to true to stop the event from bubbling.

properties.name: source
properties.summary: Source object that fired the event.

properties.name: type
properties.summary: Name of the event fired.

events.name: error
events.summary: Fired when movie playback encounters an error.

properties.name: message
properties.summary: Reason for error as a string.

properties.name: success
properties.summary: Indicates a successful operation. Returns false.

properties.name: error
properties.summary: Error message, if any returned. May be undefined.

properties.name: code
properties.summary: Error code. If the error was generated by the operating system, that system's error value is used. Otherwise, this value will be -1.

properties.name: bubbles
properties.summary: True if the event will try to bubble up if possible.

properties.name: cancelBubble
properties.summary: Set to true to stop the event from bubbling.

properties.name: source
properties.summary: Source object that fired the event.

properties.name: type
properties.summary: Name of the event fired.

events.name: fullscreen

deprecated.notes: This event has been removed in Titanium SDK 7.0.0 as of the official deprecation by Apple.

events.summary: Fired when a movie changes to or from fullscreen view.
events.description: On iOS, this event is fired at the beginning of the transition to fullscreen mode. A duration property is provided, indicating the duration of the animated transition to or from fullscreen mode.

properties.name: entering
properties.summary: true if the player is entering fullscreen mode, false if it is leaving fullscreen mode.

properties.name: duration
properties.summary: Duration of the animated transition to or from fullscreen mode, in seconds.

properties.name: bubbles
properties.summary: True if the event will try to bubble up if possible.

properties.name: cancelBubble
properties.summary: Set to true to stop the event from bubbling.

properties.name: source
properties.summary: Source object that fired the event.

properties.name: type
properties.summary: Name of the event fired.

properties.summary: Set to true to stop the event from bubbling.

properties.name: source
properties.summary: Source object that fired the event.

properties.name: type
properties.summary: Name of the event fired.

events.summary: Fired when the natural size of the current movie is determined.

events.name: preload
events.summary: Fired when the movie has preloaded and is ready to play.

events.name: resize
events.summary: Fired when the movie player is resized.

methods.name: release
methods.description: This is not usually necessary but can help if you no longer need to use the player after it is used to help converse memory.

methods.name: requestThumbnailImagesAtTimes
methods.summary: Asynchronously request thumbnail images for one or more points in time in the video.
methods.description:
The times parameter specifies an array of time values, in seconds. For each time value, the platform generates an image representing the video at that point in time.

The callback function is invoked when a thumbnail is available.

Calling this method will cancel all pending asynchronous thumbnail requests.

parameters.name: times
parameters.summary: Array of time values, representing offsets into the video, in seconds.

parameters.name: callback
parameters.summary: Callback to invoke when a thumbnail is available.

methods.name: thumbnailImageAtTime
methods.summary: Returns a thumbnail image for the video at the specified time.

properties.name: allowsAirPlay
properties.summary: Whether or not the current movie can be played on a remote device.

properties.name: autoplay
properties.summary: Indicates if a movie should automatically start playback.
properties.description: On iOS, playback starts automatically if autoplay is true and the movie is likely to finish uninterrupted. The OS determines whether the movie is likely to finish uninterrupted based on factors including the bit rate of the movie and network conditions (if the movie is being streamed from a remote source).

properties.name: backgroundView
properties.summary: Sets the background view for customization which is always displayed behind movie content.
properties.description:
To create a background behind the movie content on iOS, you can specify a background view. On iOS, you can set the backgroundColor property directly on the video player, but not a background image or background gradient. For this kind of effect, specify a background view.

Note that the background view must be sized explicitly: percentage sizes do not work properly.

The following code sample creates a video player with a background image:

var videoPlayer = Ti.Media.createVideoPlayer({
    height: 300,
    width: 300,
    backgroundView: Ti.UI.createView({
        backgroundImage: 'videoPlayerBG.png
        width: 300,
        height: 300
    }),
    borderRadius: 20,
    borderWidth: 2,
    borderColor: 'blue',
});

Note that if scalingMode is set to VIDEO_SCALING_RESIZE or VIDEO_SCALING_RESIZE_ASPECT_FILL, the playing video will fill the entire video player area, obscuring any background view.

properties.name: currentPlaybackTime
properties.summary: Current playback time of the current movie in milliseconds.

properties.name: duration
properties.summary: The duration of the current movie in milliseconds, or 0.0 if not known.
properties.description: The duration of the movie may not be available when playback is started. The durationavailable event is fired when the duration is known.

properties.name: endPlaybackTime
properties.summary: The end time of movie playback, in milliseconds.
properties.description:
On iOS, defaults to 0, which indicates natural end time of the movie. Changing the value to a value less than duration causes the movie to stop playing at the specified point. On iOS, this value is not applicable to streaming media, so 0 is returned if the current media is being streamed.

On Android, this is always the same as duration (the natural end time), and changing the value has no effect.

properties.name: fullscreen

deprecated.notes: This property has been removed for iOS in Titanium SDK 7.0.0 as of the official deprecation by Apple.

properties.summary: Determines if the movie is presented in the entire screen (obscuring all other application content).
properties.description:
Note that this must be set at different times on different platforms:

On Android, this property must be set at creation time. For example:

var player = Ti.Media.createVideoPlayer({fullscreen: true});

On Android, setting this value to true means that the video will have its own Android Activity rather than being embedded as a view.

This property was removed on iOS in SDK 7.0.0

properties.name: initialPlaybackTime
properties.summary: The start time of movie playback, in milliseconds.

properties.name: loadState
properties.summary: Returns the network load state of the movie player.

properties.name: media
properties.summary: Media object to play, as either a Ti.Filesystem.File, a Ti.Blob, or an URL String.

properties.name: mediaControlStyle
properties.summary: The style of the playback controls.

properties.name: mediaTypes
properties.summary: The type of media in the player's current item first track.

properties.name: moviePlayerStatus
properties.summary: Returns the status of the movie player.

properties.name: naturalSize
properties.summary: Returns the natural size of the movie.
properties.description:
Returns a dictionary with properties width and height. Returns 0 for both properties if not known or applicable.

The naturalsizeavailable event is fired when the natural size is known.

properties.name: overlayView
properties.summary: Use the overlay view to add additional custom views between the video content and the controls.
properties.description:
Note that the overlay view must be sized explicitly: percentage sizes do not work properly.

The following code sample creates a video player with a background image:

var videoPlayer = Ti.Media.createVideoPlayer({
    height : 300,
    width : 300,
    overlayView : Ti.UI.createView({
        backgroundImage: 'videoPlayerBG.png
        width : 300,
        height : 300
    }),
    borderRadius : 20,
    borderWidth : 2,
    borderColor : 'blue',
});

properties.name: pictureInPictureEnabled
properties.summary: Whether or not the receiver allows Picture in Picture playback.

properties.name: playableDuration
properties.summary: Currently playable duration of the movie, in milliseconds, for progressively downloaded network content, or 0.0 if not known.
properties.description: On Android, this is always the same as duration.

properties.name: playbackState
properties.summary: Current playback state of the video player.

properties.name: playing
properties.summary: Boolean to indicate if the player has started playing.

properties.name: repeatMode
properties.summary: Determines how the movie player repeats when reaching the end of playback.

properties.name: scalingMode
properties.summary: Determines how the content scales to fit the view.

properties.name: showsControls
properties.summary: Whether or not the receiver shows playback controls. Default is true.
properties.description: Clients can set this property to false when they don't want to have any playback controls on top of the visual content (e.g. for a game splash screen). This property should not be used to temporarily change the visibility of the playback controls since it will create or destroy UI elements.

properties.name: url
properties.summary: URL of the media to play.
properties.description: URL identifying a local or remote video to play.

properties.name: volume
properties.summary: Volume of the audio portion of the video.
properties.description: On iOS, this adjusts the volume of the application's session as well, and will not work if useApplicationAudioSession has been set false. On the iOS device, setting this will be accompanied by an OS-provided indicator. However, the iOS simulator does not honor this volume setting, and is a known issue with Apple's simulator.
